awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Infusion of Active and Problem-Based Learning for Teaching and Research in the Context of Transportation Disruptive Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Benedict College seeks to enhance undergraduate education by infusing active and problem-based learning strategies into computer science, engineering, mathematics, and physics courses.  The activities and strategies are evidence-based and a strong plan for formative and summative evaluation is part of the project.

A cohort of Benedict College science and engineering faculty members will incorporate the Environments for Fostering Effective Critical Thinking (EFFECT) model in their teaching and guidance of student research. EFFECT focuses on modular inquiry-based course content to develop critical thinking skills and collaborative teamwork skills. EFFECT was developed by University of South Carolina faculty members, two of whom are involved in this project. It is anticipated that applying the EFFECT model with a thematic focus on transportation disruptive technologies in both teaching and research will increase student interest, learning, retention, and research capacity. The three specific objectives are to: develop autonomous vehicles learning laboratories for teaching and research; build capacity for active and problem-based learning in the classroom; and integrate the EFFECT model in undergraduate research experiences.

por.por_cntn:
This project has adopted critical pedagogy-problem-based learning within the autonomous vehicles research theme and included summer research experiences on interdisciplinary student teams at Benedict College (BC), Columbia, South Carolina (SC), a recognized HBCU classified as Baccalaureate Colleges – Diverse Fields. Like other interdisciplinary student experiences, the summer programs combined two signature high-impact practices, undergraduate research, and collaborative assignments and projects. 

Interdisciplinary summer research experiences for undergraduates at BC were conducted over a six-year span from 2018-2023. The programs were developed in partnership among BC, R1 flagship institutions (the University of South Carolina and Clemson University), and another sister HBCU (South Carolina State University) in SC. Engineering, computing, mathematics, and sciences students, including social sciences at BC, were recruited to work in interdisciplinary teams on a research problem associated with autonomous vehicles. Multiple engineering professors and graduate students from BC and research universities supervised all student teams and supported the developing and implementation of a problem-based learning research environment.

The project aimed to prepare underrepresented students to respond to diversity and inclusion initiatives in academic graduate programs and the professional workplace in growing artificial intelligence and autonomous systems fields. The summer programs were used to expand the pipeline from BC to graduate schools in the U.S. The research experiences for undergraduate students were built upon the following principles:

 

  • Students will demonstrate knowledge of fundamentals and be proficient with computational tools as preparation for graduate studies and, ultimately, be more marketable for competitive jobs; 
  • Students will be given opportunities in supportive learning environments to develop as independent thinkers within cutting-edge research projects; and
  • Students will be encouraged to explore their passion and developed interest field, as it might not be as present in their home institution, which in turn should facilitate understanding the value of more education.

Starting in 2018, teams progressed through their collaborative experience using an adaptation of problem-based learning (PBL) pedagogy, which was selected to facilitate the beneficial impacts of students working across disciplines. Applying a PBL research framework was a new contribution and its influence on improving student engagement and sustaining research interest. This PBL-oriented research environment was established by modifying the adopted Environments for Fostering Effective Critical Thinking, or EFFECTs, a framework for classroom instruction. In this approach, each cohort was posed with a research question at the start of the summer program. Within each cohort, students worked in pairs or teams on selected aspects of the research question. A sequence of planned learning activities was conducted throughout the summer to facilitate the acquisition of conceptual knowledge and the development of skills needed to answer the question. 

 Although a PBL-based approach was infused in each summer program from 2018-2021, the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in spring 2020 significantly impacted the summer 2020 experience and, to a lesser extent, in summer 2021. And finally, in-person summer programs were restored in 2022 and 2023. In 2018-2019, the student experience was highly interactive and included numerous team activities, frequent discussions on important topics, and short trips to other institutions, including the partner institution. Because this intentional structure focused on student engagement, project control, and time management was much better. Students were able to spend more meaningful time on tasks. However, the summer program in 2020 was limited to a virtual research experience launched on short notice. One of the benefits of the virtual environment, however, was it enabled more demonstrations of computational tools and scripts. The summer program 2021 was also virtual due to COVID-19 concerns with on-campus research. This program improved upon lessons learned from the summer of 2020. 

The following conclusions were based on an interdisciplinary summer research program for undergraduate students at a predominantly undergraduate HBCU. Our findings are:

  • Participants in this program were much more likely to be enthusiastic about research than to become disenchanted with it. This was evidenced by the high degree of satisfaction with the experience and the high number of students who chose to participate more than once.
  • Collaborating with students from other disciplines and learning to work in effective teams were recognized as highlights of the program and important for success in academic and workplace environments.
  • The summer program appeared to be a stepping stone to graduate school, which is consistent with what other interdisciplinary programs have reported. Application to and enrollment in graduate programs is high. More than 10 participant students continued graduate studies.   
  • More than 50 research students were mentored through this project journey, and 100 research students were impacted. Students learned, used their experiences, and published papers to secure industrial jobs, internships, research internships, and graduate studies.
  • The project supported the development of four physical lab spaces and supplies.
